pages.title: Page 1: The Role of AI Copilots in Modern Development
pages.content:
Mentor Briefing

Todayâ€™s goal is to move from â€˜using AIâ€™ to thinking with AI. Learners will see how copilots fit into a real developer workflow, how prompt engineering shapes outcomes, and how to build their first AI-assisted component.

Opening Hook (Mentor Script)

Ask the room: â€˜If AI could write 70% of your code, what would you focus on instead?â€™ Let 2â€“3 students respond. Connect their answers to creativity, design, and debugging.

Core Teaching Points

  • Copilots augment, not replace â€” AI is your intern with infinite patience but zero context until you feed it one.
  • Shift of responsibility â€” You move from syntax â†’ strategy.
  • Speed and iteration â€” 10Ã— faster testing of ideas, but only when guided properly.

Demonstration (5 min)

Open Cursor IDE â†’ new JS file â†’ prompt ChatGPT to create a simple counter app. Run it. Show how instant code appears, then point out whatâ€™s missing (comments, accessibility, tests). This gap is where human engineers matter.

Mentor Notes

  • Pause here and emphasize that every AI model is only as good as the clarity of your instructions.
  • Encourage students to ask: â€˜What context does AI need to perform this task safely?â€™

Student Reflection

Write down one area where AI could save you an hour daily (e.g., boilerplate, docs, bug-fix).

pages.title: Page 2: Mapping AI Tools to SDLC Phases
pages.content:
Mentor Setup

This section connects yesterdayâ€™s SDLC framework to todayâ€™s tool usage. Learners will understand which AI to use, when, and why.

Teaching Flow

  1. Draw the SDLC loop on the board: Plan â†’ Design â†’ Build â†’ Test â†’ Deploy â†’ Iterate.
  2. Ask: â€˜Where could AI help most in each step?â€™
  3. Reveal table below and discuss.

Tool-SDLC Mapping

PhasePrimary AI ToolExample Use
PlanChatGPTGenerate PRDs, user stories, or architecture overviews.
DesignV0Create visual wireframes and landing pages.
BuildCursorScaffold components, manage code logic.
TestClaudeAnalyze errors, refactor, explain stack traces.
DeployChatGPT + Vercel CLIGenerate CI/CD configs and troubleshoot deploys.

Mentor Demo

Show Cursorâ€™s inline chat. Type: // TODO: Add form validation â†’ highlight line â†’ use AI to generate code. Let students observe live coding speed.

Interactive Q&A

  • Ask: Why not use ChatGPT for debugging?
  • Discuss Claudeâ€™s context limit advantage (handles large files).

Mentor Reflection Prompt

â€˜If each AI tool were a team member, what role would each play?â€™ Let students list them: ChatGPT = planner, Cursor = builder, Claude = reviewer, V0 = designer.

pages.title: Page 3: Foundations of Prompt Engineering
pages.content:
Mentor Introduction

This page teaches students to write better prompts â€” concise, contextual, and outcome-focused. The goal is not to memorize, but to think in structure.

Storytelling Introduction

Say: â€œImagine you hire a junior dev from another planet who only understands exactly what you say. Thatâ€™s your AI. If you miss one detail â€” wrong color, missing prop â€” it will still smile and give you garbage.â€

The Prompt Framework (3Cs)

  • Context: Define purpose and tech stack (e.g., â€˜You are a React engineerâ€¦â€™)
  • Constraints: Add limits (e.g., â€˜under 50 lines, Tailwind onlyâ€™)
  • Clarity: Use bullets, not prose

Example Activity

Display this comparison:

âŒ â€œMake navbar responsive.â€
âœ… â€œCreate a responsive React navbar using Tailwind, includes logo, links (Home, About, Contact), hamburger for mobile.â€

Have students rewrite two vague prompts they used yesterday using the 3C method.

Mentor Discussion

  • Ask: What detail changes AIâ€™s confidence most â€” tech stack, constraints, or tone?
  • Share sample prompt improvements live on projector.

Mini Practice

Let students type a short prompt in ChatGPT for: â€œCreate a dark-mode toggle component.â€ Have them compare results after refining it once.

Mentor Tip

Highlight how specificity and iteration create reliability â€” AI becomes predictable when trained with context.

pages.title: Page 4: Guided Build â€” Quote Generator Component
pages.content:
Mentor Objective

Guide learners through building their first fully functional UI component using Cursor AI. Focus: generation â†’ refinement â†’ testing cycle.

Setup (5 min)

  1. Open the project from Day 1 (hello-ai-engineer).
  2. Create folder components/ â†’ file QuoteGenerator.tsx.
  3. Confirm Tailwind and TypeScript are working.

Mentor Demo (10 min)

In Cursor, highlight inside the new file and type:

"Create a React component named QuoteGenerator using TypeScript.
- Display random inspirational quotes
- 'Generate Quote' button
- Fade animation
- Loading spinner
- Tailwind CSS styling
- Responsive design"

Run it. Explain the AI response: component structure, state logic, event handling.

Mentor Notes

  • Pause after generation â€” ask students: â€œWhich lines look AI-written?â€
  • Explain code review mindset: treat AI output as a first draft.

Student Hands-On (20 min)

  1. Each student modifies the component to include their own quotes.
  2. Ask Cursor: Add fade-in animation and gradient background.
  3. Run locally â†’ verify interactivity.

Common Pitfalls & Fixes

  • Quotes not changing â†’ missing onClick.
  • State not updating â†’ wrong hook import.
  • Animation not smooth â†’ missing Tailwind class.

Reflection Prompt

â€œHow long would this have taken yesterday without AI?â€ Collect answers (usually Ã—6 longer). Conclude: â€˜Prompting is your new typing.â€™

pages.title: Page 5: Debugging with AI Assistance
pages.content:
Mentor Objective

Train learners to treat AI as a debugging partner. Goal: replicate 3 realistic errors and fix them with AI guidance.

Mentor Intro (3 min)

Tell the class: â€œToday youâ€™ll break your own app on purpose. Good engineers learn by fixing.â€

Planned Error Lab (25 min)

  1. Missing Import â€” Delete useState line. Ask Cursor:
    App crashes: 'useState' is not defined. How do I fix this?
  2. Type Error â€” Change a state to any then back. Ask Claude to explain the error message and fix types.
  3. Tailwind Bug â€” Rename a class to tailwind-broken. Ask ChatGPT: Styles not applying, why?

Mentor Flow

  • Let students debug 1 issue at a time using AI of choice.
  • Encourage them to paste the exact error message into AI chat.
  • Have 2â€“3 students share solutions on screen.

Discussion (5 min)

Ask: â€œWhat patterns did AI use to solve errors?â€ Write keywords: Explain â†’ Suggest â†’ Verify.

Mentor Tip

Show the difference between Cursor (in-context) vs ChatGPT (copy-paste). Explain that contextual debugging is the future IDE paradigm.

Deliverable

Each student has a working QuoteGenerator with 3 debugged errors + commit fix: resolved debugging exercise.

pages.title: Page 6: Styling and UI Refinement with V0
pages.content:
Mentor Objective

Introduce AI-assisted design thinking using V0.dev and Cursor. Students learn to translate visual ideas into code through prompts.

Mentor Prep

  • Ensure V0.dev accounts are ready (GitHub login).
  • Demo 1 generation before students start â€” share screen.

Mentor Demo (10 min)

Prompt V0:

"Design a glassmorphism quote card for React with:
- Gradient blue-purple border
- Large serif quote text
- Lucide icon quote mark
- Subtle fade animation
- Tailwind CSS"

Download generated JSX and merge into existing component in Cursor.

Student Hands-On (25 min)

  1. Students tweak colors and fonts via prompts like Change gradient to green-teal.
  2. Install Lucide icons (npm i lucide-react).
  3. Integrate design with existing logic â†’ test responsiveness.

Mentor Checkpoint

  • Walk around the room â€” ensure each student has a unique visual variant.
  • Capture screenshots for showcase wall.

Design Reflection (5 min)

Ask: â€œHow did prompt wording change design quality?â€ Note key phrases like glassmorphism, responsive, hover animation.

Deliverable

Styled component committed with message:
feat(ui): add V0 design to QuoteGenerator

pages.title: Page 7: Testing & Quality Validation
pages.content:
Mentor Objective

Students learn structured QA testing of their own AI-generated code and verify responsive performance.

Mentor Script

Say: â€œAn AI Engineer doesnâ€™t only generate â€” they verify. Testing turns guesswork into confidence.â€

Mentor Demo (10 min)

  1. Run the app locally: npm run dev
  2. Open Chrome DevTools â†’ device toolbar.
  3. Show mobile â†’ tablet â†’ desktop transitions.
  4. Use Lighthouse (Chrome Audits) â†’ discuss performance score.

Student Activity (20 min)

Give checklist:

  • â˜‘ Button generates new quote
  • â˜‘ Spinner visible during loading
  • â˜‘ Fade animation smooth
  • â˜‘ No console errors
  • â˜‘ Responsive at 375px / 768px / 1440px

Students self-test, then peer test another studentâ€™s app.

Mentor Tip

  • Have students screen-share any bug and use AI to explain cause â†’ fix.
  • Demonstrate ChatGPT Prompt: â€œReview my component for performance issues and suggest optimizations.â€

Class Discussion (5 min)

Ask: â€œWhat kind of bugs did AI miss that humans caught?â€ â†’ usually UI spacing or accessibility.

Deliverable

âœ… Tested Quote Generator
âœ… Screenshot of working version
âœ… Peer review completed

pages.title: Page 8: Documentation & Commit Practices
pages.content:
Mentor Objective

Teach version control hygiene and project documentation with AI help.

Mentor Hook

Ask: â€œIf someone cloned your repo, could they understand your work in 2 minutes?â€

Mentor Demo (10 min)

Ask ChatGPT to generate a README.md:

Write a README.md for a project 'AI Quote Generator' built with Next.js and Tailwind.
Include: intro, features, tech stack, installation, usage, credits.

Show how to paste it into the repo â†’ preview on GitHub.

Student Task (20 min)

  1. Create or update README.md
  2. Include screenshots and a short intro paragraph
  3. Add credits: ChatGPT, Cursor, V0, Claude
  4. Commit changes:
    git add README.md
    git commit -m "docs: add project documentation"
    git push origin main

Mentor Guidance

  • Explain the importance of semantic commit messages: feat:, fix:, docs:.
  • Have 1â€“2 students read their README aloud; give feedback.

Mentor Tip

Show example of bad vs good documentation.
âŒ Bad: â€œCool project.â€
âœ… Good: Explains purpose, usage, outcome, and AI role.

Reflection

Ask: â€œIf AI wrote your README, did it truly represent your learning?â€ â†’ Emphasize personalization.

Deliverable

âœ… README committed
âœ… Screenshot in /docs
âœ… GitHub repo updated and pushed
